argumentText:
Recall the definition of Riemann integral. To prove that $f$ is
integrable we have to prove that
$\lim_{\delta \to 0^+} S^*(\delta)-S_*(\delta) =0$. Since $S^*(\delta)$
is decreasing and $S_*(\delta)$ is increasing it is enough to show that
given $\epsilon>0$ there exists $\delta>0$ such that
$S^*(\delta)-S_*(\delta)<\epsilon$.

So let $\epsilon>0$ be fixed.

By Heine-Cantor Theorem $f$ is uniformly continuous i.e.
$$\exists \delta>0\ 
   \vert x-y\vert < \delta \Rightarrow \vert f(x)-f(y)\vert <\frac{\epsilon}{b-a}.$$

Let now $P$ be any partition of $[a,b]$ in $C(\delta)$ i.e. a partition
$\{x_0=a, x_1,\ldots,x_N=b\}$ such that $x_{i+1}-x_i<\delta$. In any
small interval $[x_i,x_{i+1}]$ the function $f$ (being continuous) has a
maximum $M_i$ and minimum $m_i$. Since $f$ is uniformly continuous and
$x_{i+1}-x_i<\delta$ we have $M_i - m_i < \epsilon/(b-a)$. So the
difference between upper and lower Riemann sums is
$$\sum_i M_i(x_{i+1}-x_i) - \sum_i m_i(x_{i+1}-x_i)
  \le \frac{\epsilon}{b-a} \sum_i (x_{i+1}-x_i) = \epsilon.$$

This being true for every partition $P$ in $C(\delta)$ we conclude that
$S^*(\delta)-S_*(\delta)<\epsilon$.
names: proof of continuous functions are Riemann integrable
